text: (upbeat music)
It's a huge honor
to have been selected for the Talented Twelve.
I'm extremely grateful, you know,
to have been selected for the people that nominated me
and who have helped me along the way.
So, before I get into the chemistry
I just want to give a quick overview of who I am.
I'm a native of Iowa.
Born 34 years ago, in beautiful Iowa.
So, after high school, I didn't really know what to do,
so, I started at community college
and then transferred to the University of Northern Iowa
where I was initially pre-med.
And it was the Organic Chemistry class that I took
that really sparked my interest
and led me to switch my career to chemistry.
And I was fortunate enough to do
some really nice undergraduate research with Martin Chen,
who is an excellent advisor,
and he encouraged me to do a PhD.
So, I followed his sage advice
and I did my PhD with John Hartwig
at the University of California, Berkeley.
I did various things,
mostly around fluorine
and fluorinated functional groups with copper.
And it was during my PhD,
that I also became interested in process chemistry,
specifically in the pharmaceutical sector.
I got a little taste of that
by developing a multi-kilo scale synthesis
of what John turned,
the Trifluoromethylator
which is shown in the top right there.
So, this was commercialized through several vendors.
And then in 2015,
I was fortunate enough to land my dream job
and start as a process chemist at Merck
in Rahway, New Jersey.
Now, where I've been ever since.
And really the highlight of my career
has been the work I did last year and this year
as a Process Chemistry lead for molnupiravir
which is Merck's oral antiviral for COVID-19,
which I'll get to at the end of the talk.
You know, so as a process chemist
in the pharmaceutical sector,
the types of molecules that I work with
on a day-to-day basis look like the one shown here.
So, there's a lot of Lewis basic heteroatoms,
their sensitive functionality
and complex physical chemical properties.
And a few functional groups that are particularly prevalent
are phenols, pyridines, and sulfonamides.
So, you know, I'm interested in not only methods
to access these functional groups,
but also manipulate them in complex settings,
such as the ones shown here.
For example, how could we functionalize
a pyridine in this setting
or functionalize a sulfonamide or make a phenol,
sorry, I guess my pointer doesn't work.
Make the, you know, phenols shown in the bottom right.
And well, I'll tell you about first is
some independent research projects that I did
while at Merck that were not related to process chemistry.
So, I'm a process chemist full time,
but I do find some time in the day to develop new methods.
And really where this all started is
for the transformation shown here,
which is the conversion of electron portal aryl halides
to phenols.
And at first glance,
this looks like a trivial transformation.
You say, oh,
I can just take hydroxide and do SNAr to make the phenol,
but in reality that doesn't work.
Hydroxide is a poor nucleophile
and the products are often more reactive for SNAr.
So, you know, in my first year at Merck,
I started talking with a colleague of mine,
Kevin Maloney who was next door to my office.
And, you know, we shared a lot of common interests
and one of them was developing new methods
and we both thought that this would be
an interesting transformation.
And, you know, it's a long story,
but I'll cut to the punchline
is that we were able to develop
what we're terming these hydroxide surrogate ratings.
So, in this instance,
we developed reactions with acetohydroxamic acid,
out just under the box.
And this reacts under mildly basic conditions
because the OH bond is acidic
and the oxygen anion is an excellent nucleophile.
So, you can run these reactions under mild conditions,
the intermediate shown in the box,
then fragments itself under the same reaction conditions
through a loss and rearrangement so during these phenols.
So, that's Kevin there shown in the middle in the picture.
And we published this in 2016.
And it immediately took off internally,
which I'll get back to in a second.
There were some limitations of this of course,
you need an electron pore aryl halide coupling partner.
So, we wanted to expand this more broadly.
So we, we looked at palladium and copper catalyzed methods,
but there was issues with this reagents
over the sensitive activity.
And also the loss and rearrangement did not occur
unless the aromatic group has electron pores.
So, we went back to the drawing board
and we ultimately developed this
other hydroxide surrogate reaction
using benzaldehyde oxime.
We developed both palladium and copper-catalyzed methods
to allow for a really broad scope
for the conversion of, you know,
electronically and circularly diverse aryl halides
to phenols.
And we published two papers in 2017.
And, you know, really, you know,
what excites me about doing these side projects is
not only it's really fun to work with Kevin,
who's, you know, a great friend and colleague,
but the fact that this chemistry has been used extensively.
So, when I checked a few months ago,
this was used over 800 times at Merck so far
and it's used, you know,
on a daily basis, essentially.
It's also been used in a couple of cases on multi-kilo scale
for the supply of clinical material.
And it's routinely used across other pharm industries.
And it's also been used in a handful of cases
in the academic setting.
So for example,
the Illudinine Total Synthesis by Greg Dudley.
I won't read the text here,
but basically no other conditions work,
but our hydroxide surrogate strategy work.
And if you wanna hear more,
I'll refer you to episode two
of my colleague's Pharm to Table podcast.
So, this is a podcast put on by L.C. Campeau
who's in the left on the photo up top
and then Dani Schultz,
two excellent colleagues.
So, I encourage you to check out their podcast.
So, switching gears.
So, I mentioned in the introduction
that pyridines are extremely prevalent and as you know,
one of the most common heterocycles
in pharmaceutical chemistry.
So, in grad school I recognized this
and was interested in developing methods
for the selective functionalization of these.
So in 2013,
I developed this method for the fluorination of pyridines
using silver diamine fluoride.
And these reactions occurred with exquisite sites activity,
and, you know, really broad scope.
And the fluorinated products are okay as final products,
but they're really versatile synthetic intermediates,
where you can do SNAr with a variety of nuclear props.
And this chemistry is great,
but there are a few limitations, right?
Use of psychometric silver,
silver too is a strong oxidant, a strong Lewis acid.
So, there are some issues
with functional group compatibility.
So, when I came to Merck,
I was interested in developing
maybe a more process-friendly variant of this.
So, I built this bifunctional region,
which is shown in the box there.
This oxime derivative.
And the way this works is that
it reacts with pyridines to make this,
to make the electron-like pyridinium salt,
which is perinuclear condition.
And then that intermediate can undergo base mediated
re-aromatisation which reacts
via the loss of acetamide trial
and breaking the [inaudible] area of the sulfonate.
And these re-aromatizes your pyridine
to make these new compiled substitute pyridines.
And shortly after that,
this was commercialized by Sigma-Aldrich
and a few other vendors.
So, it's available for people around the world.
And it's chemistry was good.
It was, you know, interesting from a mechanistic,
mechanistic point of view,
but the substrate scope of the respect
of what nucleophile you can use was quite limited.
And it was primarily limited to things like cyanide,
for example.
So, I had a extremely talented intern
or he was a graduate student at the time, Suhong Kim.
Kevin worked with me for the Summer in 2019.
And we developed what we term "The Aminator",
which kind of addresses some of the function
compatibility issues in the previous paper.
So, this reagent is completely different,
but it works in a similar fashion.
That it activates the pyridine ring,
it has the two electron oxygen
and also delivers the nitrogen source.
So, I won't go into all the details or the mechanism.
I'll leave that up to the audience to figure out
or you can read this paper.
So again, switching gears to the third and final topic
of the independent research projects
is the late stage functionalizion of sulfonamides.
Of course, you know,
molecular editing is a buzzword these days,
so I think this really fits the bill.
So, you know, again,
Kevin and I were just chatting one day
and we're really interested in transformations,
such as the one shown here.
How can you take, for example,
a primary sulfonamide in some complex setting
that has multiple nitrogen heterocycles,
multiple, you know, basic functionality
and then selectively convert the NH2 group
of a primary sulfonamide to things like sulfones,
other sulfonamides, sulfonic acid
and so on and so forth.
So, of course this looks impossible on paper, but you know,
Kevin's an extremely creative guy and, you know, we,
we put our minds together and came up with,
what I think is a pretty interesting solution.
So, the general reaction mechanism shown here,
we're able to take primary sulfonamides
with benzaldehyde as a strict metric reductant.
You form these sulfinyl imines transiently in situ
and then C catalyst breaks these down
Foluso benzonitrile.
So, benzaldehyde oxides, benzonitrile
and your sulfonamides is reduced to a sulfonate,
out just under the box.
And once you have these sulfonates
that are extremely versatile intermediates
but can react with electrophiles
and your phenolic cross-couplings and so on and so forth.
So, through this pathway
we're able to do transformation such as the one shown here.
For example, on the left,
you can take this fairly complex sulfonamides
and selectively convert the NH2 group to a methyl group.
And in the right hand side,
you can take Celebrex and convert the NH2 group to,
for example, N15 NH2 for labeling,
which is important in drug discovery and development.
And you can also do transformation
that completely the removed the sulfonyl group
to generate, for example, bi-arrow compounds.
And this work was also scaled up to appreciable scale
and published in Organic Syntheses last year.
You know, so looking at this,
this initial paper was focused on primary sulfonamides,
but we want it to look more broadly.
How can we take, for example,
any secondary sulfonamides and selectively functionalize
any part of it that we want.
For example, switching the sulfur for a carbon
or cutting out nitrogen or switching any of the R-groups
in a late stage fashion.
And again, at the time this was completely unknown in it,
and it looks kind of silly on paper
that this would even be proposed.
But again, long story short,
and I'm cutting out some of the details
in the interest of time,
but we were able to develop conditions that allow for
transformation such as the one I just showed.
So, you can see here in the bottom left,
we can take this fairly complex sulfonamides
and convert it into an amide
by effectively replacing the SO2 group with a CO group.
And on the bottom right-hand side,
you can see that we take this and ethanesulfonamide
and convert it to a methylsulfonyl,
essentially excising nitrogen from a molecule.
And subtle changes like this
are important in drug discovery,
where you want to make minor tweaks
of a complex molecule to lead to new drug candidates.
All right.
So, that was some of the independent research
that I've done while at Merck,
predominantly with, you know,
my friend and colleague Kevin Maloney.
But of course I'm a process chemist by day.
And I was extremely honored
to have been selected to lead the efforts
for the process chemistry side for molnupiravir.
Which is internally known as MK-4482.
So, it's the compound shown on the top right,
this nucleoside derivative
and it's being investigated as,
it's being investigated as an antiviral for COVID-19.
This is an orally-dosed drug.
And the way it works is at the oxime functional group
on the heterocycle can switch between two tautomeric forms.
So, in the oxime form it can act like uridine.
And then the hydroxylamine form,
it can act like cytidine.
So in the RNA polymerase enzyme
this leads to viral error catastrophe
by causing all these mutations
and effectively killing the virus.
So, this is currently in phase III clinical trials.
The readout is expected imminently
within the next few weeks.
And the hope is that we would apply
for emergency use authorization before the end of the year.
And you know, this has been all over the news.
I'm sure, you know,
people have come across molnupiravir.
There was the headline on CNN.com yesterday,
was about this drug.
It's demonstrated very exciting antiviral activity
against SARS-CoV-2 in humans.
And it has, you know, really promising,
I guess it's very promising to help end the pandemic.
So, I won't go into all the details again
in the interest of time,
but there was two efforts for the molnupiravir team.
So, one of them was what we referred to as Gen 1
the first generation synthesis,
where we start from uridine
and there's a five-step synthesis
to convert it to molnupiravir.
So, we acquired a baseline process
when we partnered with Ridgeback
to develop this therapeutic.
And we had a few months to really improve the yields
and make it a robust process
so we can supply the world with this drug.
So again, I won't go into the details,
but over the five steps,
we were able to improve the yield by a factor of 1.6
and improve overall throughput and productivity
by a factor of two.
Meaning we can make twice as much material
as we would have otherwise.
So, this commercial process has been completed and validated
and implemented in five different countries.
To date, we made around 75,000 kilos of this drug,
which is around 350 million capsules
for the treatment of about 10 million people.
And this, this number is going up every day
about a metric ton per day on average.
And, you know we did a lot of improvements
as well to green chemistry,
you know, with,
with an eye towards green chemistry to prevent waste
and the improvements and the scale is done on meaning,
means that we're saving several millions
of kilos of waste each year.
And, you know,
this Gen 1 process is great,
it's what's used to supply the world,
but we also wanted to develop the ideal process.
So, the Gen 1 process starts from uridine
which is itself made from ribose and uracil .
So, we also came up with this
really short streamlined synthesis,
starting from ribose.
There's an enzymatic esterification
with isobutyric anhydride
to generate this non-isolated intermediate [inaudible]
and then a really elegant biocatalytic cascade
installs the uracil ring.
Generate this isobutyl uradine
intermediate as our only isolated intermediate.
And I really can't take credit for really any of this work.
This was done by my excellent colleagues
in the Biotalysis Merck Engineering Groups
to develop this extremely elegant cascade.
And I'm working with some process chemistry colleagues
to figure out isolation's and the process.
And in this final step
that is quite elegant dehydration method
developed primarily by my colleague, Steve Silverman,
to convert the carbonyl group into an oxime.
And this occurs in high yield using simple reagents.
So, overall compared to the baseline process
this is two-thirds fewer steps
and two-and-a-half fold higher yielding.
And it's approximately 50% cost of goods reduction.
And thank you Bethany for highlighting this work
earlier this year, and this,
this paper should be published imminently
in the next few days, so.
So, with that, I'll first thank all the colleagues
that I worked with for molnupiravir.

and so on and so forth.
These are, you know,
this wouldn't have been possible

And it's really amazing to have been able to
lead the process chemistry efforts
and work with these folks.
And then, you know, on a more personal note,
I'd like to thank the folks shown here.

my incredible wife who's dialed-in.
Hi, Rebecca.
Amazing person to partner with
and really amazing scientist.
Huge, thanks to John Hartwig, who I think is also online.
Hello, John.
Amazing mentor.

So thank you, John.

the co-inventor of "Aminator".

And L.C. and you know,
the rest of the Merck leadership team,

And of course,
thank you again to anyone who nominated me

So, with that I'd be happy to answer any questions.
Thank you so much, Patrick.
As you pointed out,
I've been following the molnupirvir synthesis.
And I was just wondering if, you know,
there's any plans to move forward with the Gen 2 process?
Very good question. Yes.
So at, as of right now,
there are not, the plans.
Because we are committed to making
so much material with Gen 1
and we've already made so much.
That from the forecast it doesn't necessarily make sense.
But the pandemic is,
you can't predict it, right?
So, if demand goes up, if,
you know this really is going to be used heavily,
then there is the potential that we would revisit Gen 2.
